citation.article-title: Clostridium saccharogumia sp. nov. and Lactonifactor longoviformis gen. nov., sp. nov., two novel human faecal bacteria involved in the conversion of the dietary phytoestrogen secoisolariciresinol diglucoside.

p.s: Description of Lactonifactor longoviformis gen. nov., sp. nov.
L. longoviformis (long.o.vi.for.mis. L. adj. longus long, L. neut. n. ovum egg, L. masc. adj. suffix -formis shaped like. N.L. masc. adj. longoviformis-shaped like a long egg).
The bacterium has the features of the genus.
Cells are 1.0–1.5 μm wide, 1.5–3.0 μm long, may occur in pairs and are often fusiform.
They do not grow at pH values below 5.5 and above 9.3.
The species does not necessarily require cysteine as a reducing agent to grow.
It utilises fructose, galactose, glucose, mannose, melezitose, melibiose, raffinose, ribose, sucrose and sorbitol as the sole energy and carbon source.
Cells catalyse the conversion of lignans with a butane-1,4-diol structure to lignans with a butyrolactone structure.
Colonies on Columbia-agar are circular, entire, pinpoint to 2 mm in diameter, convex, opaque, greyish white and non-hemolytic.
The major cellular fatty acid is 16:0 (22.2%).
The type strain ED-Mt61/PYG-s6T(=DSM 17459T=CCUG 51487T) was isolated from faeces of a healthy human male adult.
Its G+C content of DNA is 48.0 mol%.
The strain did not grow in the presence of penicillin or rifampicin at concentration as low as 0.5 μg mol−1.
